message.en-EN: Calculating minus × minus is a repeated subtraction of the minus, so it ends up being a repeat of the plus.

message.ja-JA: 借金1000円を3回返済したら、[(-1000円)×(-3回)]って式になるワケです。
message.en-EN: If you repay a debt of 1,000 yen three times, the formula becomes [(-1,000 yen) × (-3 times)].

message.ja-JA: どうでしょう？  「引き算の集合体」という点を見落とされがちなんですが、そこさえ分かれば理由は簡単ですよね？
message.en-EN: What do you think?  The point that it is a "subtraction collection" is often overlooked, but once you understand that, the reason is simple, isn't it?

message.ja-JA: うーん、まあ、確かに、分かるっちゃ分かる
message.en-EN: Hmm, well, sure, I know.

message.ja-JA: 割り算の場合も計算ルール自体は掛け算と同じです。計算式側にあるマイナスのかず分だけ、答え側のプラスマイナスが逆転します。
message.en-EN: The calculation rules for division are the same as for multiplication. The plus/minus on the answer side is reversed by the amount of minus on the calculation formula side.

message.ja-JA: [6÷3=2]を例にすると、[6÷(-3)]なら、計算式側のマイナスの数が1つなので、答え側が1回逆転して答えは(-2)になります
message.en-EN: Taking [6÷3=2] as an example, if it is [6÷(-3)], there is one negative number on the calculation side, so the answer side will be reversed once and the answer will be (-2).

message.ja-JA: [6÷(-3)=2]の場合なら、計算式側のマイナスの数が2つなので、答え側も2回逆転して、答えはプラス2になります
message.en-EN: In the case of [6÷(-3)=2], there are two negative numbers on the formula side, so the answer side is also reversed twice and the answer becomes plus 2.

message.ja-JA: 割り算って、逆数の掛け算に直せる、ってルールがありましたよね？　だからマイナスの数の場合も、割り算は掛け算と同じルールが通じるんですね
message.en-EN: There's a rule that says division can be converted into multiplication of reciprocals, right? So even in the case of negative numbers, the same rules apply for division as for multiplication.

message.ja-JA: ああ……、確かにそんなのあったけど……、うーん、何だか分かるような分からないような……
message.en-EN: Ah... I'm sure there was something like that, but... hmm, I feel like I don't know what it is...

message.ja-JA: まあ、いきなりそう簡単にはスパッと理解なんて出来ませんよね？
message.en-EN: Well, it's not that easy to understand all of a sudden, right?

message.ja-JA: 先ほどもお話したように、マイナスの数というのは、「頭では理解できても何だかしっくりこない」となかなか受け入れられなかった歴史があります
message.en-EN: As I mentioned earlier, negative numbers have a history of being difficult to accept, with people saying, ``Even if you understand it intellectually, it doesn't quite sit right with you.''

message.ja-JA: だから、説明されたところで「すぐには納得できない」と感じてしまったとしても、仕方ないコトでしょう
message.en-EN: So even if you feel like you can't understand it right away after it's e×plained to you, it can't be helped.

message.ja-JA: ただ、1度覚えてしまえば計算ルール自体は簡単です。使っている内に慣れていきますよ。
message.en-EN: However, once you remember it, the calculation rules themselves are easy. You'll get used to it as you use it.

message.ja-JA: そういうのキラーイ
message.en-EN: I hate that kind of thing

message.ja-JA: さて、いかがだったでしょうか？
message.en-EN: So, what do you think?

message.ja-JA: マイナスの数の計算は、世界中の人々が「なんか納得できない」と拒否し続けてきた、実は非常に厄介な計算です
message.en-EN: Calculating negative numbers is actually a very troublesome calculation that people all over the world have rejected, saying it doesn't make sense.

message.ja-JA: 覚えてしまえば計算は簡単にできるかもしれませんが、「こんな計算、何の役に立つんだ？」みたいに感じさせてくるでしょう
message.en-EN: Calculations may be easy once you memorize them, but they may make you wonder, "What's the use of these calculations?

message.ja-JA: 多くの人たちを数学嫌いにさせてきた、中学数学の最初の関門といっても過言ではありません
message.en-EN: It is no e×aggeration to say that it is the first gateway to middle school mathematics that has made many people dislike mathematics.

message.ja-JA: あまりややこしく考えずに、「ああ、借金の計算のことでしょ」くらいに気楽に捉えましょう
message.en-EN: Don't think about it too complicatedly, just take it casually and say, ``Oh, it's about calculating debt, right?''

message.en-EN: I don't think about debt lightly.
